awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   CT-M:   Hardware Containers for Software Components
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on hardware features 
to improve the security of software systems.
By refining the coarse-grained protections available in
today's architectures, the project will aim to protect
the integrity of individual software objects or components.
The hardware mechanisms force tight controls on 
the execution of software components, which
programmers can define to be as large as entire
applications or as small as individual objects. 
The goal is to rapidly detect and also recover from attacks that
improperly access memory or take over the CPU.
The approach also includes hardware-supervised
recovery, to enable systems to return to normal 
operation after an attack and to protect the recovery 
process itself from attacks.

The benefits of this project include the ability to 
thwart a large class of attacks and the potential of
developing more robust software systems in the future.
Recovery, which has received somewhat less attention than
attack prevention or detection, is especially important for 
embedded systems that do not have the luxury of intervention 
by human operators.

The project will be used to train graduate students and to 
feed material into graduate courses taught at the three 
participating universities. Modules will also be developed for 
use in K-12 education with the aim of drawing students into 
considering careers in computer science and engineering.

por.por_cntn:
This research project focused on the following question: since modern software is developed by integrating libraries and components, how can hardware provide support so that these components are properly isolated from each other to prevent one component from maliciously or inadvertently affecting the behavior of other components. The main outcome of the project is an architectural design, together with a full performance evaluation, that shows how to achieve such hardware support with relatively modest penalty in overall performance. A key outcome was a memory protection scheme that exploits execution characteristics of programs to minimize the amount of extra information that must be stored to prevent unauthorized accesses to memory. A second outcome was to align the hardware support with the popular object-oriented paradigm in software. Several challenges regarding object support were addressed in this project. In both cases, the scheme for memory protection needed to address fine-grained protection to align with object boundaries, and to make memory protection work for the dynamic memory allocated at runtime for objects. The project funded the education, development and research training of graduate students, some of whom are themselves now advancing research in this area. The project also enabled funding of undergraduate research, which has played a role in motivating some of the brighter students towards advanced degrees in computer science.
